title: Production of single- and multiple-gene-modified mice via maternal SpCas9-based gene editing
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Timing: 3 days: Preparation and gene editing of maternal SpCas9-containing zygotes; zygote transfer into pseudopregnant mice
Timing: 7 days: Collection of gene-edited blastocysts
Timing: 22 days: Gestation of gene-modified mice
Details regarding IVF, zygote transfer, and cesarean sections can be found in various laboratory manuals/previous reports (e.g., Behringer et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). In this protocol, these procedures are described only with regard to the key points. (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1])
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_17.csv
Generating mice with single-gene modifications
Timing: 3 days for step 1
Timing: 10 min for step 1d
Timing: 30 min for step 1e
Timing: 10 min for step 1f
Timing: ∼40 min for step 1g
Timing: 2 days for step 2
Timing: 2 days for step 3
Timing: ∼20 min for step 4a-d
Timing: ∼10 min for step 4e-f
Timing: ∼ 5 min for step 4g-i
Timing: ∼5 min for step 4j-n
Timing: 3–5 min per operation (1 h after zygote collection; around 15:30–16:30) for step 4o-r
Timing: ∼5 min per operation for step 4s-u
Timing: 1–3 h for step 5
Timing: 3–4 h for step 6
Timing: 1–3 h for step 7
Timing: 2 h (T7EI), 2–3 days (Seq) for step 8c
Timing: 2 h (Cas9RNP), 4–5 days (TA-cloning and sequencing), 2 days (sequencing and ICE) for step 8f
Timing: 2 h (RE), 4–5 days (TA-cloning and sequencing) for step 8m
Generation of Zygotes Harboring Maternal SpCas9
Day −3 Evening (Superovulation; 18:30); inject 5–7.5 IU pregnant mare serum gonadotropin (PMSG) intraperitoneally into 3–5 sCAT female mice (3–4-week-old (Tg/+ or Tg/Tg, depending on the purpose) or 10 sCAT female mice (8–12-week-old (Tg/+ or Tg/Tg depending on the purpose) (See troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]).
Note: For 3–4 week-old sCAT females, approximately 30–50 eggs were obtained per mouse. For 8–12 week-old sCAT females, approximately 10–30 eggs were obtained per mouse.

Note: When the IVF pair of sCAT female (Tg/+) × male (+/+) is used, pups with and without the SpCas9 transgene can be obtained.
Day −1 evening (superovulation; 18:00–18:20); inject 5–7.5 IU human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) intraperitoneally into the sCAT females primed with PMSG on day −3.
Day −1 evening; for day 0 IVF implementation:
Set up culture dishes. Place several 100-μL droplets (for sperm culture) and several 200-μL droplets (for egg culture) of mHTF+BSA in a 3.5-cm Petri dish and layer droplets with paraffin oil to prevent evaporation.
Place the dish in a CO2 incubator (5% CO2, 37°C) for 12– 13 h.
Day 0 (07:30–08:00; sperm collection):
Remove a dish for sperm incubation from the CO2 incubator.
Collect the sperm mass from the cauda epididymis of a sCAT male (+/+), place it in 100-μL mHTF+BSA drops on the sperm incubation dish and return the dish to the CO2 incubator.
Day 0 (08:00–09:20; egg collection):
During sperm incubation (1.5–2 h), collect the egg mass from the ampulla of the oviduct tube of superovulating sCAT females.
Place them in the 200-μL mHTF+BSA drops on the egg culture dish and return the dish to the CO2 incubator.
Day 0 (09:30); insemination):
Remove dishes for sperm and egg incubation from the CO2 incubator.
Using a 20-μL pipettor, add sperm solution containing approximately 8000–20,000 sperms to 200-μL mHTF+BSA drops containing eggs in the egg culture dish. We used a hemocytometer to estimate sperm counts.
Return the dish to the CO2 incubator until use (next part g-ii).
After insemination, prepare the required number of dishes to be used for culturing zygotes. Place 9 × 30-μL drops of KSOM+BSA media per 3.5-cm dish and layer with paraffin oil to prevent evaporation (zygote culture dish).

Maintain the dishes in a CO2 incubator (5% CO2, 37°C) for 4 h until use (next part g-v).
Day 0 (4 h after insemination around 13:30; zygote collection):
Place several 100–200-μL drops of KSOM+HEPES+BSA in the dish (zygote-washing dish). Use this dish for washing zygotes.
Remove the egg culture dishes from the CO2 incubator.
Collect the eggs released from the second polar body from the drops in the dishes, using a self-made embryo handling pipette from a Pasteur glass tube (tip diameter, 150–200 μm), the tip of which should be tapered using a gas burner.
Wash polar body-released eggs in the drops in the zygote-washing dish.
Subsequently, remove the zygote culture dish prepared in the morning from the CO2 incubator and collect the eggs extruded from the second polar body in the drops in the dishes.
Return the dishes to the CO2 incubator and maintain the dishes at 37°C in a 5% CO2 environment for 1 h until the electroporation step for gene editing (step 4j).
Note: In our results, the ratio of second polar body extruded eggs per the total number of eggs was approximately 50%–90%.
Prepare the foster parent ICR females We performed ICR mating on day −2 to obtain females one day after delivery at day +18 as a foster. The mating performance achieved in our laboratory was approximately 50%.
Day −2 evening; mate 4–8 ICR females (8–16-week-old) in estrus and ICR males (8–20-week-old) to obtain the 2–4 foster parent ICR females.
Day −1 morning (at approximately 09:00); check the plug of ICR females mated with males. Females with plugs should be separated from males and kept in one breeding cage.

Prepare the recipient parent ICR females We performed ICR mating at day −1 to obtain females for zygote transfer at day +19 as a recipient. The mating performance achieved in our laboratory was approximately 50%.
Day −1 evening; mate 6-12 ICR females (8–16-week-old) in estrus and vasectomized ICR males (8–20-week-old) to obtain the 3–6 zygote-recipient parent ICR females.
Day 0 morning (from approximately 07:00–09:00); check the plug of ICR females mated with vasectomized males. Females with plugs are separated from males and kept in one breeding cage.
Electroporation Day 0, preparation of the electroporation solution for delivering sgRNA or sgRNA+ssODN into the zygote
Prepare 20 μL of klf5 sgRNA solution (50–400 ng/μL in 75% DPBS) or 20 μL of klf5 sgRNA + ssODN solution (50–400 ng/μL + 800 ng/μL in 75% DPBS) in a 0.2 mL PCR tube. 20 μL of (50–400 ng/μL) klf5 sgRNA solution
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_18.csv
or 20 μL of sgRNA + ssODN solution (50–400 ng/μL + 800 ng/μL
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_19.csv
Heat the tube at 75°C for 5 min and then keep it at 21°C–25°C for 5–10 min.
Thereafter, add 20 μL of Opti-MEM (final sgRNA concentration, 25–200 ng/μL or sgRNA + ssODN of 25–200 ng/μL + 400 ng/μL in a 1:1 mixture of 75% DPBS and Opti-MEM).
Keep on ice until use. Day 0, electroporator setting (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4])
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/646-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Setup of the electroporation system for the delivery of sgRNAs or sgRNA+ssODN into sCAT zygotes
(A) Electroporation system used in this study.
(B) CUY21EDIT II electroporator (BEX Co., Tokyo, Japan).
(C) Display of the CUY21EDIT II.
(D) Electroporation chamber with platinum electrodes (#LF501PT1-10; BEX Co.).
(E) A self-made embryo handling pipette.
(F) Two dishes for washing zygotes before and after electroporation. Bar = 2 cm.
Set up the electroporation system for gene editing (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A–4F).

i.A stereoscopic microscope (Olympus SZX16, Tokyo, Japan)
ii.An electroporator (CUY21EDIT II electroporator; BEX Co., Tokyo, Japan) (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B–4C)
iii.A pair of platinum electrodes set in a glass plate (#LF501PT1-10; 1-mm gap, 10-mm length, 3-mm width, and 0.5-mm height; BEX Co.) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D)
iv.A self-made embryo-handling pipette (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E), as described in the zygote collection section (step 1g.-iii of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details])
Turn on the power of the CUY21EDIT II and upload the program.
i.Electroporation conditions (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C)
ii.Constant 20 V
iii.Switching between on and off for 3 ms and 97 ms, respectively
iv.5 cycles
Alternatives: Electroporators from other manufacturers can be used (e.g., Nepa Gene Co., Ltd., Chiba, Japan). However, the electroporation conditions need to be optimized by investigators.
Day 0, preparation of the two dishes for washing zygotes before and after electroporation (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]F and 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5])
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/646-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. The two 3.5-cm dishes for washing zygotes before and after electroporation
(A) Zygote washing dish I.
(B) Zygote washing dish II. Arrow, 100-μL drop of 1:1 medium of 75% DPBS and Opti-MEM. Arrowhead, 5–10 μL drop of sgRNA or sgRNA+ssODN solution. Bar = 1 cm.
For zygote washing dish I, place several 200-μL droplets of KSOM+HEPES+BSA in the 3.5-cm dish (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A).
For zygote washing dish II (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B)
First, place a glass cover slip (Matsunami Glass Ind., Ltd., Osaka, Japan) in the 3.5-cm dish.
Thereafter, place a 100-μL drop of 1:1 medium (75% DPBS:Opti-MEM) (arrow, Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B) on the cover slip.
Then place a 5–10 μL drop of sgRNA or sgRNA+ssODN solution (arrowhead, Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]B) on the cover slip.
Cover the dish with the lid to prevent evaporation of the medium when not in use. Day 0, washing sCAT zygotes immediately before electroporation

Critical: These operations should be performed in the shortest possible time to reduce stress on the zygotes.
Remove the zygote culture dish from the CO2 incubator.
Transfer 10–40 zygotes to the drop in washing dish I and wash them using a self-made embryo-handling pipette from a Pasteur glass tube (tip diameter, 150–200 μm; Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]E).
Select zygotes containing two pronuclei and a second polar body (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Thereafter, transfer the selected zygotes to the 1:1 medium drop in washing dish II and transfer them to the drop containing sgRNA or sgRNA+ssODN in washing dish II.
Hold them in this drop until electroporation. Day 0, implementation of electroporation for sCAT zygotes (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6])
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/646-Fig6.jpg
Figure 6. Electroporation chamber with platinum electrodes, and placement of the sCAT zygotes between electrodes
(A) A platinum electrodes set in a glass plate (#LF501PT1-10; BEX Co.).
(B and C) sCAT zygotes are arranged in a straight line. Bar = 1 mm.
Critical: These operations should be performed rapidly to reduce stress on the zygotes.
CAUTION: To avoid an electric shock, never touch the platinum electrodes when you press the electroporator program switch.
Fill the gap between the electrodes (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D and 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]A) with 5 μL of sgRNA or sgRNA+ssODN solution.
Thereafter, transfer the zygotes (10–40) in the drop in washing dish II into the gap between the electrodes (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B).
Arrange them in a row as shown in Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]B and 6C.
Press the program switch and let the current flow once (See troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3]).
Note: In our results, the EDIT II electroporator records approximately 100–200 mA.
Day 0, washing sCAT zygotes immediately after electroporation
Critical: Transfer the electroporated zygotes to the drop in washing dish I (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A) in the shortest possible time, as the Opti-MEM is harmful to the zygotes.

Transfer the electroporated zygotes to the drop in washing dish I using a self-made embryo-handling pipette.
Keep them at 21°C–25°C for 5 min and then return them to the drop in the zygote culture dish.
Return the dish to the CO2 incubator.
sCAT zygote transfer (1 h after electroporation [Day 0; around 17:30]) The electroporation-treated zygotes are transplanted into the oviducts of recipient ICR females via the conventional method of mouse embryo oviduct transfer (for example, Behringer et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]), approximately 1 h after the electroporation treatment. Zygote transfer methods can be found in various laboratory manuals/previous reports (e.g., Behringer et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). In this protocol, this procedure has been described only with regard to the key points.
Transfer 10–20 zygotes in both oviducts (5–10 zygotes per oviduct) of the embryo-recipient ICR females (step 3 of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]).
Note: Embryo-recipient ICR females lacking swollen ampulla of the uterine tube were not used for zygote transplantation.
Alternatives: For analysis at the blastocyst stage, zygote culturing continued for 4 days without zygote transplantation (step 6 of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]).
(OPTIONAL) a blastocyst assay for time-saving indel or KI genotyping (Sakurai et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5])
Use the blastocysts derived from the electroporation-treated zygotes cultured in vitro for 4 days without zygote transplantation (See troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5])
Transfer a blastocyst into each 0.2-mL PCR tube using a self-made embryo handling pipette.
Add 10–12 μL of the blastocyst lysis solution to each tube. Lysis solution 100 mL (Autoclaved and stored at −20°C)
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_20.csv
Blastocyst lysis solution 1 mL (Store on ice until use)
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_21.csv
Heat at 56°C for 10 min and then at 95°C for 10 min.
Store on ice until use.
Pause Point: The heated solution can be stored at −20°C for several months.

Use the Tks Gflex DNA Polymerase Kit (TAKARA) in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions. Prepare the following PCR reaction reagents per sample:
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_22.csv
Run the two-step PCR as follows:
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_23.csv
Electrophorese 2.5 μL of the PCR solution in a 1% agarose gel (TAE buffer). Observe the PCR products (expected size, 1113 bp)
Note: The different size or several bands of PCR product observed are attributed to indel or KI mutations.
Purify the remaining PCR products using the FastGene Gel/PCR Extraction Kit (Nippon Genetics) and elute the PCR products by adding 25 μL ddH2O to the center of the kit’s spin column. The purified PCR products can be used for a T7 Endonuclease I (T7EI) assay or Sanger DNA template sequences.
For the analysis of indel mutations, prepare the following mixtures per sample:
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_24.csv
∗ The PCR products derived from non-klf5 sgRNA-treated samples are used as a wild-type control.
Heat at 95°C for 5 min and then store at 21°C–25°C for 30 min∼
Add 2 μL of T7EI ( 0.5–1 U/ μL) to the heated mixtures and incubate them at 37°C for 1–2 h.
Electrophorese 15 μL of the solution in a 2%–3% agarose gel (TAE buffer).
Determine klf5 indel mutation (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/646-Fig7.jpg
Figure 7. Representative T7 endonuclease I (T7EI) analyses of the klf5-sgRNA target DNA region
Lanes 1, 2, and 4 show indel mutations. Lane 3 shows a non-indel mutation. WC: wild-type control.
For the analysis of KI mutations, prepare the following mixtures per sample:
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_25.csv
Incubate at 37°C for 1 h
Electrophorese 10 μL of the Cla I-treated mixture in a 1% agarose gel (TAE buffer).
Determine klf5 KI mutation (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/646-Fig8.jpg
Figure 8. Our representative determination of a knockin (KI) mutation of the klf5 gene via restriction enzyme digestion and Sanger sequencing

(A) Determination of KI of the 3× FLAG tag with a Cla I site into the klf5 gene. Lane 2 shows a mono-allelic KI, lane 3 shows a bi-allelic KI, while lanes 1 and 4 show non-KI products.
(B) Sequence of the 5′ and 3′ junction site in a klf5+ 3× Flag KI pup.
Perform Sanger sequencing with the PCR primers; CR(klf5)-1S or CR(klf5)-1A in the same way as described in step 13 of before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] if you need to confirm the indel or KI mutation sequence (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B).
Delivery of foster and recipient mother ICR The foster ICR mice are used when zygote-transferred ICR females were subjected to a cesarean section on Day +19. The recipient mice usually give birth 19 days after zygote transfer. If the pups were not delivered by the afternoon on the 19th day, they were harvested through a cesarean section (for example, Behringer et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]). In this case, the foster ICR female(s) nursed them, and female cages were not replaced for about 7–10 days after birth of the offspring. Day +18, delivery of foster mother ICR
Check the delivery of foster mother ICR (step 2 of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]) by the afternoon.
Adopt the mother ICR calmy holding pups (observe milk line, white around the stomach) for the foster if needed on the next day (next part). Day +19, delivery of recipient mother ICR
Check the delivery of the zygote-transferred mother ICR (step 3 of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]) by the afternoon.
Continue to breed females that have been confirmed to give birth until Day 40–49.
Carry out cesarean section if the mice do not give birth by the afternoon. The pups can be raised in foster ICR (step 7b of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]) (See troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7]).

Note: A tentative evaluation of gene editing rates in the offspring is possible using genomic DNA extracted from the placenta recovered during the cesarean section (step 8 of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details])
Offspring genotyping Around days +40 to 49, the pups are weaned from the ICR foster females. The gene editing efficiency for the pups is to be evaluated using the methods described hereafter. Subsequent phenotypic analysis is performed for the obtained gene-edited pups. Furthermore, mating and breeding will be carried out to obtain offspring for further phenotypic analysis, confirming the establishment of a mouse strain (See troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]).
Extract genomic DNA from an ear fragment or tail biopsy of the offspring using the DNeasy Blood & Tissue Kit (QIAGEN #69504) in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions.
Perform PCR with primers CR(klf5)-1S or CR(klf5)-1A and 50–100 ng of the genomic DNA extracted as a template, purified in the same way as described in step 6f–l of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]. For indel mutations, use T7EI analysis and Sanger sequencing
Perform T7EI analysis with the purified PCR products described in step 6j (see Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7] as similar analysis).
Perform Sanger sequencing with PCR primers CR(klf5)-1S or CR(klf5)-1A as described in step 13 of before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] and step 6-l of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details].
Analyze the sequence using free WEB programs (for example, the Inference of CRISPR Edits (ICE) software; Synthego Corporation, Silicon Valley, CA, USA) in accordance with program instructions (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/646-Fig9.jpg
Figure 9. On- and off-target genotyping of klf5 gene in the fetuses developed from klf5 sgRNA-electroporated sCAT zygotes
(A) A representative result of on-target genotyping via the ICE software.
(B) A representative result of on-target genotyping via CLUSTALW software.
(C) A representative result of PCR genotyping of 3 candidate off-target regions of the klf5 gene (Sakurai et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]).

For the zygosity of indel mutations, use a Cas9RNP cutting assay or sequencing analysis via TA cloning of the purified PCR product or via a free WEB program (ICE software)
Perform the Cas9RNP cutting assay with purified PCR products as described in steps 30–37 of before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]). See Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10] as a representative result.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/646-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. Representative determination of zygosity for indel mutations of the klf5 gene using the Cas9 RNP cut assay
Lane 1 shows a biallelic indel. Lanes 2 and 3 show monoallelic indels, while lane WC shows a wild-type control.
Carry out TA cloning of the purified PCR product using the Mighty TA-cloning Reagent Set Kit (TAKARA #6019).
Add A-overhang to the PCR product as follows, per sample:
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_26.csv
Incubate at 65°C for 5 min.
Mix the following reagents:
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_27.csv
Add 5 μL of Ligation Mighty Mix (total 10 μL) and incubate for 0.5–1 h.
Transform 25 μL of competent bacteria (JM109, Dh5a) with 2.5 μL of the ligation solution and plate the bacteria on an LB-Ampicillin (50–100 μg/mL) agar plate.
Incubate the plate for 12 –15 h at 37°C.
Perform a colony PCR of 3–5 bacterial colonies with specific PCR primers M13 Rev and M13 M4 as described in before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin] step 11. Electrophorese the PCR solution (5–10 μL) in a 1% agarose gel (TAE buffer).
M13 Rev: CAGGAAACAGCTATGAC
M13 M4: GTTTTCCCAGTCACGA
Inoculate 2–3 positive bacterial colonies separately in 2 mL of LB-Ampicillin (50–100 μg/mL) medium and incubate for 8 h– 15 h at 37°C.
Isolate and purify the PCR product–ligated PMD20-TA (step 20 of before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]).
Perform Sanger sequencing with PCR primers CR(klf5)-1S or CR(klf5)-1A and the purified plasmid (200–300 ng) as described in step 13 of before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin].

Analyze the sequence using one of several free Multiple Sequence Alignment WEB programs (for example, CLUSTALW, https://www.genome.jp/tools-bin/clustalw[href=https://www.genome.jp/tools-bin/clustalw]) in accordance with the manufacturer’s instructions (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]B).
Alternatives: Without using TA-cloning, directly perform Sanger sequencing with PCR primers CR(klf5)-1S or CR(klf5)-1A and the purified PCR products (20–30 ng, step 8b) as described in step 13 of before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin].
Analyze the sequence using a free WEB program (for example, ICE software), in accordance with the program instructions (see Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]A for a similar analysis).
Note: Bindel-PCR, non-sequencing-based method (Sakurai et al., 2019[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]), can be used for the determination of zygosity.
For KI mutation, use restriction enzyme (RE) analysis of PCR products and sequencing analysis by TA cloning of the purified PCR product.
Perform RE analysis with the PCR products in the same way as described in step 6k of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details] (see Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]A for a similar analysis).
Perform sequencing analysis by TA cloning of the purified PCR product in the same way (step 8g-k of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details], see Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]B for a similar analysis). Use sequencing analysis for off-target mutations (OPTIONAL)
Perform PCR with the PCR primer sets klf5Offt1-1/2, klf5Offt2-1/2, and klf5Offt3-1/2, as well as 50–100 ng of the genomic DNA extracted as a template (8a), purified as described in step 30 of before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin].
Perform direct Sanger sequencing with these PCR primers and the purified PCR products (20–30 ng) as described in step 13 of before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin].
Analyze the sequence with free WEB programs CLUSTALW or ICE in accordance with program instructions (Figure 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig9]C).
Generation of mice with multiple gene modifications
Timing: ∼20 min

For generating mice with multiple mutations, the same procedure was performed except for the preparation of electroporation solution for delivering sgRNA or sgRNA+ssODN into the zygote (steps 4a–d of step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]). We performed 10 simultaneous genetic modifications in Sakurai et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]. However, if necessary, a number of sgRNAs in the range of 2–9 can be selected (See troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9]).
Herein, we only describe the preparation of an electroporation solution for the delivery of 10 sgRNAs with various target sites (Sakurai et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]).
Day 0, preparation of the electroporation solution for delivering 10 sgRNAs into the zygote
Prepare 30 μL of mixed sgRNAs (50 ng/μL per sgRNA, total 500 ng/μL in 75% DPBS) in a 0.2-mL PCR tube.
table:files/protocols_protocol_646_28.csv
Heat the tube at 75°C for 5 min and then keep it at 21°C–25°C for 5–10 min.
Thereafter, add 30 μL of Opti-MEM (final sgRNA concentration, 25 ng/μL per sgRNA, total 250 ng/μL in a 1:1 mixture of 75% DPBS and Opti-MEM).
Keep on ice until use (60 μL in the 1:1 medium).
Note: In our analysis (Sakurai et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]), the upper limit of sgRNA concentration of the mixture solution was set to 250 ng/μL. However, up to approximately 400 ng/μL would be considered possible (unpublished data). If necessary, each sgRNA concentration can be increased to >25 ng/μL to increase the biallelic mutation rate. However, when targeting a gene whose functional deficiency causes lethality, the sgRNA concentration is to be preferably maintained at approximately 25 ng/μL (Sakurai et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8]).
